The researchers used a piezoelectric organic material, which converts mechanical energy to electrical energy and vice versa, to make needle-shaped crystals that aren't more than 2 mm long or 0.2 mm wide, according to the experimental results which were [published in the journal Science](https://science.sciencemag.org/content/373/6552/321.abstract). Due to their molecular arrangement in the specially designed crystals, a strong attractive force developed between two surfaces. Every time a fracture occurred, [the attractive forces joined the pieces back again](https://interestingengineering.com/scientists-create-the-worlds-toughest-self-healing-material), without needing an external stimulus such as heat or others that most self-healing materials would need.
